policy.doc.name: Incubator Policy
section.name: podling reporting
policy.statement: each podling in incubation must report to the incubator pmc.

policy.doc.name: Incubator Policy
section.name: podling reporting
policy.statement: podlings shall report monthly for their first three months, after that quarterly.

policy.doc.name: Incubator Policy
section.name: podling reporting
policy.statement: the incubator pmc may, at their discretion, ask a podlings to report more frequently.

policy.doc.name: Incubator Policy
section.name: podling reporting
policy.statement: the ppmc with the mentor(s) help, must produce a report for the incubator pmc detailing overall progress toward graduation and any issues the podling has encountered.

policy.doc.name: Incubator Policy
section.name: website
policy.statement: there are restrictions on where podlings can host their websites and what branding they can use on them.

policy.doc.name: Incubator Policy
section.name: branding
policy.statement: there are restrictions about how podlings can use their own and other asf brands and names.

policy.doc.name: Incubator Policy
section.name: publicity
policy.statement: there are some restrictions about how podlings can advertise themselves, especially in press releases related to podlings.

policy.doc.name: Incubator Policy
section.name: disclaimers
policy.statement: podling web sites must include a clear disclaimer on their website and in all documentation, releases and release announcements stating that they are in incubation.

policy.doc.name: Incubator Policy
section.name: disclaimers
policy.statement: a podling has a choice of two disclaimers: a standard disclaimer or a work-in-progress disclaimer.

policy.doc.name: Incubator Policy
section.name: disclaimers
policy.statement: podlings wishing to use a different disclaimer message must have the incubator pmc approve it before use.

policy.doc.name: Incubator Policy
section.name: standard disclaimer
policy.statement: podlings wanting to follow all asf policy on releases should use the following text for all disclaimers (replace the underlined text as appropriate):

policy.doc.name: Incubator Policy
section.name: standard disclaimer
policy.statement: apache podling-name is an effort undergoing incubation at the apache software foundation (asf), sponsored by the name of apache tlp sponsor .

policy.doc.name: Incubator Policy
section.name: standard disclaimer
policy.statement: incubation is required of all newly accepted projects until a further review indicates that the infrastructure, communications, and decision making process have stabilized in a manner consistent with other successful asf projects.

policy.doc.name: Incubator Policy
section.name: standard disclaimer
policy.statement: while incubation status is not necessarily a reflection of the completeness or stability of the code, it does indicate that the project has yet to be fully endorsed by the asf.

policy.doc.name: Incubator Policy
section.name: standard disclaimer
policy.statement: for releases, the text should be included in a separate disclaimer file stored alongside the notice and license files.

policy.doc.name: Incubator Policy
section.name: work in progress disclaimer
policy.statement: podling wishing to make releases that may not follow all asf policy should use the following disclaimer (replace the underlined text where needed):

policy.doc.name: Incubator Policy
section.name: work in progress disclaimer
policy.statement: apache podling-name is an effort undergoing incubation at the apache software foundation (asf), sponsored by the name of apache tlp sponsor .

policy.doc.name: Incubator Policy
section.name: work in progress disclaimer
policy.statement: incubation is required of all newly accepted projects until a further review indicates that the infrastructure, communications, and decision-making process have stabilized in a manner consistent with other successful asf projects.

policy.doc.name: Incubator Policy
section.name: work in progress disclaimer
policy.statement: while incubation status is not necessarily a reflection of the completeness or stability of the code, it does indicate that the project has yet to be fully endorsed by the asf.

policy.doc.name: Incubator Policy
section.name: work in progress disclaimer
policy.statement: some of the incubating project's releases may not be fully compliant with asf policy.

policy.doc.name: Incubator Policy
section.name: work in progress disclaimer
policy.statement: for example, releases may have incomplete or un-reviewed licensing conditions.

policy.doc.name: Incubator Policy
section.name: work in progress disclaimer
policy.statement: what follows is a list of issues the project is currently aware of (this list is likely to be incomplete):

policy.doc.name: Incubator Policy
section.name: work in progress disclaimer
policy.statement: list of known issues goes here

policy.doc.name: Incubator Policy
section.name: work in progress disclaimer
policy.statement: if you are planning to incorporate this work into your product/project, please be aware that you will need to conduct a thorough licensing review to determine the overall implications of including this work.

policy.doc.name: Incubator Policy
section.name: work in progress disclaimer
policy.statement: for the current status of this project through the apache incubator, visit: https://incubator.apache.org/projects/ apache podling-name .html

policy.doc.name: Incubator Policy
section.name: work in progress disclaimer
policy.statement: for releases, the text should be included in a separate disclaimer-wip file stored alongside the notice and license files.

policy.doc.name: Incubator Policy
section.name: releases
policy.statement: the podling can make non-asf releases while incubating as long as it is moving towards making asf releases.

policy.doc.name: Incubator Policy
section.name: releases
policy.statement: podlings must not perform any asf releases of software without the approval of the incubator pmc.

policy.doc.name: Incubator Policy
section.name: releases
policy.statement: when a podling decides it wants to make an asf release, the podling must hold a vote on their public dev list.

policy.doc.name: Incubator Policy
section.name: releases
policy.statement: at least three +1 votes are required (see the apache voting process page) and more +1 votes than -1 votes.

policy.doc.name: Incubator Policy
section.name: releases
policy.statement: if the vote passes, the podling must send a summary of that vote to the incubator's general list and request that the incubator pmc approve the release.

policy.doc.name: Incubator Policy
section.name: releases
policy.statement: three +1 incubator pmc votes are required to approve a release.

policy.doc.name: Incubator Policy
section.name: releases
policy.statement: should the incubator pmc vote to approve a release, the podling may make that release available to the public under these conditions:

policy.doc.name: Incubator Policy
section.name: releases
policy.statement: the release archive(s) must include the word "incubating" in the filename.

policy.doc.name: Incubator Policy
section.name: releases
policy.statement: the release archive(s) must contain a disclaimer (see above), which should be placed in a disclaimer or disclaimer-wip file.

policy.doc.name: Incubator Policy
section.name: releases
policy.statement: releases for the podling must be distributed through http://www.apache.org/dist/incubator/ podling.

policy.doc.name: Incubator Policy
section.name: releases
policy.statement: the podling may choose to distribute approved releases through other channels by following the guidelines here .

policy.doc.name: Incubator Policy
section.name: adding ppmc members
policy.statement: after voting someone into the ppmc on the ppmc private list, the podling must send a notice email to the private@incubator list.

policy.doc.name: Incubator Policy
section.name: adding ppmc members
policy.statement: the ppmc must wait for 72 hours before inviting the new ppmc member to join the ppmc.

policy.doc.name: Incubator Policy
section.name: joining the ipmc
policy.statement: as with all pmcs, new the ipmc votes on proposed members on the private@incubator list.

policy.doc.name: Incubator Policy
section.name: joining the ipmc
policy.statement: after a vote has finished, the ipmc must send a notice email to the board

policy.doc.name: Incubator Policy
section.name: joining the ipmc
policy.statement: and then wait for 72 hours before inviting the proposed member.

policy.doc.name: Incubator Policy
section.name: joining the ipmc
policy.statement: any asf member can ask to be an ipmc member, without a vote, but the ipmc must still give notice to the board.

policy.doc.name: Incubator Policy
section.name: termination
policy.statement: the incubator pmc should notify a podling of any policy violations.

policy.doc.name: Incubator Policy
section.name: termination
policy.statement: it may consider termination of a podling that does not correct such violations.

policy.doc.name: Community Guide
section.name: what is an open and diverse community?
policy.statement: a major criterion for podling graduation to top level project (tlp) status is to have developed an open and diverse meritocratic community.

policy.doc.name: Community Guide
section.name: people
policy.statement: as a project grows, it needs to renew itself by accepting new committers.

policy.doc.name: Community Guide
section.name: people
policy.statement: a project needs to learn how it can recruit new developers and committers into the community.

policy.doc.name: Community Guide
section.name: people
policy.statement: the openness of the community is not only measured by the number of contributors.

policy.doc.name: Community Guide
section.name: people
policy.statement: open and respectful discussions on the mailing lists are vital.

policy.doc.name: Community Guide
section.name: people
policy.statement: community members must learn ways to resolve technical conflicts without destroying personal relationships.

policy.doc.name: Community Guide
section.name: communication
policy.statement: email lists are the lifeblood of apache communities. they are the primary mode of discourse and constitute a public and historical record of the project.

policy.doc.name: Community Guide
section.name: communication
policy.statement: other forms of communication (p2p, f2f, personal emails, instant messaging platform posts, and so on) are secondary.

policy.doc.name: Community Guide
section.name: communication
policy.statement: if a project uses alternative forms of communication, it is essential to try to minimize the chances of problems arising.

policy.doc.name: Community Guide
section.name: communication
policy.statement: all matters of substance need to move back to the email lists.

policy.doc.name: Community Guide
section.name: communication
policy.statement: projects need to preserve, and post back to the lists, significatn conversation threads in other channels.

policy.doc.name: Community Guide
section.name: communication
policy.statement: project should post regular reminders that other secondary forms of communication exist.

policy.doc.name: Community Guide
section.name: communication
policy.statement: there is a limited number of topics, such as security issues and discussions about people, which it is best to handl in private.

policy.doc.name: Community Guide
section.name: communication
policy.statement: as much business of the project as possible should take place on public lists, but the private list is available for matters of a sensitive nature.

policy.doc.name: Community Guide
section.name: communication
policy.statement: good netiquette requires that you seek permission from the poster before making public posts made to a private list.

policy.doc.name: Community Guide
section.name: community building
policy.statement: before a podling graduates, it must create a diverse and self-sustaining community.

policy.doc.name: Community Guide
section.name: community building
policy.statement: to address this challenge, committers may need to devote more time to community-building and less to development.

policy.doc.name: Community Guide
section.name: community building
policy.statement: if the podling's software has lots of users but very few new developers, the community needs to do more work to encourage users to become developers.

policy.doc.name: Community Guide
section.name: community building
policy.statement: however, once a project gains momentum, it may be more productive for the long-term health of a project to encourage users to propose solutions to non-critical problems and, thus, become more involved.

policy.doc.name: Community Guide
section.name: community building
policy.statement: try to encourage expert users to answer questions.

policy.doc.name: Community Guide
section.name: community building
policy.statement: try to encourage users to become developers.

policy.doc.name: Community Guide
section.name: community building
policy.statement: when they give a good answer that the documentation doesn't cover, ask them to submit a patch.

policy.doc.name: Community Guide
section.name: community building
policy.statement: when users suggest a good design or extension, ask for volunteers to help implement it rather than just coding it up.

policy.doc.name: Community Guide
section.name: helping developers become committers
policy.statement: to become an apache committer, a developer needs to hang around long enough to accumulate a track record of contributions.

policy.doc.name: Community Guide
section.name: helping developers become committers
policy.statement: it may also be that the committer bar is set too high.

policy.doc.name: Community Guide
section.name: helping developers become committers
policy.statement: promptly reviewing patches or pull requests is essential.

policy.doc.name: Community Guide
section.name: helping developers become committers
policy.statement: provide credit in the commit message and when closing the issue.

policy.doc.name: Community Guide
section.name: helping developers become committers
policy.statement: it's also good to encourage developers by suggesting new related work they may like to volunteer to work on.

policy.doc.name: PPMC Guide
section.name: podling project management committee (ppmc)
policy.statement: each podling project management committee (ppmc) helps its podling learn how to govern itself.

policy.doc.name: PPMC Guide
section.name: podling project management committee (ppmc)
policy.statement: initially, it is composed of the podling's mentors and the initial committers.

policy.doc.name: PPMC Guide
section.name: podling project management committee (ppmc)
policy.statement: the ppmc is directly responsible for the oversight of the podling, and it also decides who to add as a ppmc member.

policy.doc.name: PPMC Guide
section.name: private email list
policy.statement: a private email list named private@ project lets the ppmc discuss confidential topics.

policy.doc.name: PPMC Guide
section.name: private email list
policy.statement: most communication should be on the podling's dev list!

policy.doc.name: PPMC Guide
section.name: private email list
policy.statement: the private list is only for confidential discussions that should not be made public, such as the suitability of a particular individual to become a committer or a member of the ppmc.

policy.doc.name: PPMC Guide
section.name: private email list
policy.statement: the mentors should verify that all ppmc members are subscribed to the private list.

policy.doc.name: PPMC Guide
section.name: private email list
policy.statement: each member of the ppmc should be on the dev list, so posting to dev is sufficient.

policy.doc.name: PPMC Guide
section.name: private email list
policy.statement: each member of the incubator pmc is on the incubator general list, so posting to the general list is sufficient.

policy.doc.name: PPMC Guide
section.name: podling status reports
policy.statement: on a monthly basis, the ipmc collects reports from each incubating project and sends them to the asf board.

policy.doc.name: PPMC Guide
section.name: podling status reports
policy.statement: watch the incubator general email list for when these become due.

policy.doc.name: PPMC Guide
section.name: podling status reports
policy.statement: the incubator report includes the status of a subset of the incubating projects.

policy.doc.name: PPMC Guide
section.name: podling status reports
policy.statement: currently, new podlings report to the incubator monthly for the first three months, then quarterly after that.

policy.doc.name: PPMC Guide
section.name: podling status reports
policy.statement: the ppmc does not have to fill out the report itself; the ppmc is just responsible for making sure that it gets filled out.

policy.doc.name: PPMC Guide
section.name: podling status reports
policy.statement: it is better to discuss the report on the dev list and ask everyone to contribute to it.

policy.doc.name: PPMC Guide
section.name: podling status reports
policy.statement: if mentors disagree with the posted report, they should say so; otherwise, the incubator pmc assumes that the report speaks for the community.

policy.doc.name: PPMC Guide
section.name: podling status reports
policy.statement: mentors must sign off on podling reports.

policy.doc.name: PPMC Guide
section.name: podling status reports
policy.statement: - if there is no mentor sign off, the ipmc will not accept the report from that podling; it will have to submit a new report in the following month.

policy.doc.name: PPMC Guide
section.name: podling status reports
policy.statement: add your podling reports to the incubator wiki:

policy.doc.name: PPMC Guide
section.name: podling status reports
policy.statement: - add each podling report to the incubator wiki

policy.doc.name: PPMC Guide
section.name: podling status reports
policy.statement: - follow the instructions in your report reminder, and post on the month year page, with the provided template

policy.doc.name: PPMC Guide
section.name: project status page
policy.statement: in addition to the quarterly status reports, each podling has a page on the incubator web site that tracks its status (see the complete list for examples).

policy.doc.name: PPMC Guide
section.name: maintaining the podling roster
policy.statement: maintain your podling roster in whimsy podling roster .

policy.doc.name: PPMC Guide
section.name: adding committers
policy.statement: adding committers is one of the most important functions of any pmc, including incubator podlings.

policy.doc.name: PPMC Guide
section.name: adding committers
policy.statement: there are no asf-wide rules on how to decide when to invite someone to become a committer. experience shows that it's best to keep the bar low.

policy.doc.name: PPMC Guide
section.name: adding committers
policy.statement: most projects use formal [discuss] and [vote] threads on the private email list, and others use a more "lazy" consensus approach.

policy.doc.name: PPMC Guide
section.name: adding committers
policy.statement: the podling incubator reports should document any committers added since the previous report.

policy.doc.name: PPMC Guide
section.name: adding committers
policy.statement: if the podling decides in favor of the potential committer, it offers committership to the nominee.

policy.doc.name: PPMC Guide
section.name: adding committers
policy.statement: if the nominee accepts the responsibility of being a committer for the project, the nominee formally becomes an apache committer.

policy.doc.name: PPMC Guide
section.name: adding committers
policy.statement: the proposer then asks an ipmc member (typically one of the mentors) to follow the documented procedures to complete the process.

policy.doc.name: PPMC Guide
section.name: adding committers
policy.statement: if the nominee is already an apache committer on another project, the ipmc member can add the nominee as a committer on the podling via the whimsy podling roster .

policy.doc.name: PPMC Guide
section.name: adding committers
policy.statement: the proposer then directs the new committer to the apache developer's pages , to the apache incubator site and to the incubator committers guide for important additional information.

policy.doc.name: PPMC Guide
section.name: voting in a new ppmc member
policy.statement: it should be a goal of a podling to have all committers participate in the ppmc.

policy.doc.name: PPMC Guide
section.name: voting in a new ppmc member
policy.statement: the ppmc should take an active role in watching committers develop as community participants.

policy.doc.name: PPMC Guide
section.name: voting in a new ppmc member
policy.statement: they should identify those who are participating at a community level (not just a technical one), and approach them with an offer of ppmc membership.

policy.doc.name: PPMC Guide
section.name: voting in a new ppmc member
policy.statement: any member of the ppmc can propose a new member of the ppmc.

policy.doc.name: PPMC Guide
section.name: voting in a new ppmc member
policy.statement: the proposal should be discussed in private on the ppmc's private email list, with a subject line of "[discuss] joe bob ppmc membership".

policy.doc.name: PPMC Guide
section.name: voting in a new ppmc member
policy.statement: if there is consensus that the proposed member is suitable, there should be a formal vote with the subject line of "[vote] joe bob ppmc membership" on the ppmc's private email list.

policy.doc.name: PPMC Guide
section.name: voting in a new ppmc member
policy.statement: if the vote is successful, a member of the ppmc sends a message to the ppmc private email list, with the subject line of "[vote][result] joe bob ppmc membership".

policy.doc.name: PPMC Guide
section.name: voting in a new ppmc member
policy.statement: the nominating ppmc member should send a message to the ipmc ( private@incubator.apache.org ) with a reference to the vote result in the following form:

policy.doc.name: PPMC Guide
section.name: voting in a new ppmc member
policy.statement: to: private at incubator.apache.org

policy.doc.name: PPMC Guide
section.name: voting in a new ppmc member
policy.statement: cc: private at podling.incubator.apache.org

policy.doc.name: PPMC Guide
section.name: voting in a new ppmc member
policy.statement: subject: [notice] joe bob for podling ppmc

policy.doc.name: PPMC Guide
section.name: voting in a new ppmc member
policy.statement: body:

policy.doc.name: PPMC Guide
section.name: voting in a new ppmc member
policy.statement: joe bob has been voted as a new member of the *podling* ppmc. the vote thread is at: *link to the vote thread*

policy.doc.name: PPMC Guide
section.name: voting in a new ppmc member
policy.statement: note that there is a grace period of 72 hours from when the ppmc sends the notice to the ipmc to when the ppmc should formally invite the proposed member.

policy.doc.name: PPMC Guide
section.name: voting in a new ppmc member
policy.statement: this is an important part of the overall process.

policy.doc.name: PPMC Guide
section.name: voting in a new ppmc member
policy.statement: failure to do this can result in an embarassing situation for people involved.

policy.doc.name: PPMC Guide
section.name: voting in a new ppmc member
policy.statement: in the email you send, replace podling with your podling's actual name, and replace joe bob with the person's actual name.

policy.doc.name: PPMC Guide
section.name: voting in a new ppmc member
policy.statement: after 72 hours, the ppmc should invite joe bob to join it, using message like this .

policy.doc.name: PPMC Guide
section.name: voting in a new ppmc member
policy.statement: once the proposed member has accepted, a moderator for the ppmc mail list accepts the new member's subscription request.

policy.doc.name: PPMC Guide
section.name: adding mentors
policy.statement: a mentor must be an ipmc member.

policy.doc.name: PPMC Guide
section.name: adding mentors
policy.statement: people who are not ipmc members can still help out in an informal capacity.

policy.doc.name: PPMC Guide
section.name: adding mentors
policy.statement: ipmc members are free to volunteer to mentor a podling.

policy.doc.name: PPMC Guide
section.name: adding mentors
policy.statement: to do so, they should mail the podling stating their intentions.

policy.doc.name: PPMC Guide
section.name: adding mentors
policy.statement: the podling should then decide whether it wants to add the mentor.

policy.doc.name: PPMC Guide
section.name: adding mentors
policy.statement: if the podling decides to add the mentor, it should do so in the whimsy podling roster .

policy.doc.name: PPMC Guide
section.name: adding mentors
policy.statement: if a podling is in a position where they feel they need a new mentor, they can drop an email on the general incubator email list to try to recruit a one.

policy.doc.name: PPMC Guide
section.name: removing a mentor
policy.statement: after discussing it with the ppmc you can have someone with access (another mentor) remove the mentor via whimsy.

policy.doc.name: PPMC Guide
section.name: ppmc and binding votes
policy.statement: the only time when a ppmc member's vote is binding is for the addition of new ppmc members and committers.

policy.doc.name: PPMC Guide
section.name: ppmc and binding votes
policy.statement: release votes are only binding for ipmc members.

policy.doc.name: Apache Cookbook
section.name: does our project fit the apache incubator?
policy.statement: donating your project to the asf means giving up control of it, and its trademarks if any.

policy.doc.name: Apache Cookbook
section.name: does our project fit the apache incubator?
policy.statement: to give our "podlings" (incubating projects) the best chances of success, we usually ask them to enter the incubator with at least the start of a community built around an existing codebase.

policy.doc.name: Apache Cookbook
section.name: what are the steps to becoming an apache software foundation top-level project?
policy.statement: to achieve this, an incoming project ("podling") goes through the following steps:

policy.doc.name: Apache Cookbook
section.name: what are the steps to becoming an apache software foundation top-level project?
policy.statement: find a champion and incubation mentors and discuss and prepare an incubation proposal

policy.doc.name: Apache Cookbook
section.name: what are the steps to becoming an apache software foundation top-level project?
policy.statement: decide to incubate at the asf

policy.doc.name: Apache Cookbook
section.name: what are the steps to becoming an apache software foundation top-level project?
policy.statement: discuss the proposal with the incubator pmc

policy.doc.name: Apache Cookbook
section.name: what are the steps to becoming an apache software foundation top-level project?
policy.statement: if needed, refine the list of initial committers and mentors in the proposal

policy.doc.name: Apache Cookbook
section.name: what are the steps to becoming an apache software foundation top-level project?
policy.statement: if needed, refine the proposal based on incubator pmc feedback

policy.doc.name: Apache Cookbook
section.name: what are the steps to becoming an apache software foundation top-level project?
policy.statement: let the incubator pmc vote on the proposal

policy.doc.name: Apache Cookbook
section.name: what are the steps to becoming an apache software foundation top-level project?
policy.statement: set up the podling's infrastructure

policy.doc.name: Apache Cookbook
section.name: what are the steps to becoming an apache software foundation top-level project?
policy.statement: start building a community around the podling's code

policy.doc.name: Apache Cookbook
section.name: what are the steps to becoming an apache software foundation top-level project?
policy.statement: invite new committers and ppmc members

policy.doc.name: Apache Cookbook
section.name: what are the steps to becoming an apache software foundation top-level project?
policy.statement: make podling releases and document and refine both the code and the release process

policy.doc.name: Apache Cookbook
section.name: what are the steps to becoming an apache software foundation top-level project?
policy.statement: when you feel ready to graduate, assess the podling's readiness with the incubation mentors

policy.doc.name: Apache Cookbook
section.name: what are the steps to becoming an apache software foundation top-level project?
policy.statement: if applicable, prepare the transfer of existing trademarks to the asf

policy.doc.name: Apache Cookbook
section.name: what are the steps to becoming an apache software foundation top-level project?
policy.statement: discuss graduation with the incubator pmc

policy.doc.name: Apache Cookbook
section.name: what are the steps to becoming an apache software foundation top-level project?
policy.statement: start the graduation vote with the incubator pmc, leading to an asf board resolution to establish the tlp

policy.doc.name: Apache Cookbook
section.name: communicating with the incubator
policy.statement: to communicate with the incubator pmc use the public link:+https://lists.apache.org/list.html?

policy.doc.name: Apache Cookbook
section.name: finding a champion and mentors
policy.statement: to enter the incubator, your project needs a champion and at least two or three mentors .

policy.doc.name: Apache Cookbook
section.name: finding a champion and mentors
policy.statement: these people need to be part of the incubator pmc, which asf members can join just by asking.

policy.doc.name: Apache Cookbook
section.name: finding a champion and mentors
policy.statement: the champion helps the incoming podling in the process of creating their proposal and acts as a liaison between the podling and the incubator pmc for the initial steps, at least until the podling's proposal is accepted.

policy.doc.name: Apache Cookbook
section.name: finding a champion and mentors
policy.statement: they may stay on to act as a mentor after that.

policy.doc.name: Apache Cookbook
section.name: finding a champion and mentors
policy.statement: the mentors accompany the podling through all phases that lead to graduation as a top-level project.

policy.doc.name: Apache Cookbook
section.name: finding a champion and mentors
policy.statement: the starting point is usually to find a champion.

policy.doc.name: Apache Cookbook
section.name: finding a champion and mentors
policy.statement: for that you might write to the general@incubator.a.o list with a brief description of your project, with relevant links, mentioning that you are looking for a champion and trying to get people interested.

policy.doc.name: Apache Cookbook
section.name: finding a champion and mentors
policy.statement: or, if you know any asf members or incubation mentors, ask them directly if they would be willing to help.

policy.doc.name: Apache Cookbook
section.name: creating an incubation proposal
policy.statement: the champion helps the podling prepare an incubation proposal that describes the incoming project for the initial discussions with the incubator pmc.

policy.doc.name: Apache Cookbook
section.name: discussing the incubation proposal
policy.statement: once the proposal is ready, the podling representatives send it to the general@incubator.a.o list for discussion, with a subject line like [discuss] foo proposal to raise the incubator pmc's attention.

policy.doc.name: Apache Cookbook
section.name: discussing the incubation proposal
policy.statement: once the discussion phase is finished, the champion or a podling representative starts a [vote] thread on the general@incubator.a.o list.

policy.doc.name: Apache Cookbook
section.name: discussing the incubation proposal
policy.statement: the vote happens according to the asf voting rules .

policy.doc.name: Apache Cookbook
section.name: discussing the incubation proposal
policy.statement: in short, it takes place on the incubator email list, lasts at least 72 hours, and is a majority vote by the incubator pmc members, with others being welcome to cast votes.

policy.doc.name: Apache Cookbook
section.name: podling infrastructure setup
policy.statement: once the incubator pmc votes to establish the podling, its infrastructure can be set up. usually, the champion or incubation mentors drive this process.

policy.doc.name: Apache Cookbook
section.name: podling infrastructure setup
policy.statement: however, it can also be driven by podling community members if they know how to proceed.

policy.doc.name: Apache Cookbook
section.name: publicity and announcements
policy.statement: project can not issue press releases or other public statements about joining the asf before the incubator pmc accepts the podling.

policy.doc.name: Apache Cookbook
section.name: publicity and announcements
policy.statement: there are also some restrictions about how podlings can advertise themselves and especially around press releases related to podlings.

policy.doc.name: Apache Cookbook
section.name: importing the initial code
policy.statement: a specific process exists do donate code to the asf, which podlings also need to follow, based on software grants and/or cclas .

policy.doc.name: Apache Cookbook
section.name: community building
policy.statement: during incubation, the podling is expected to build and expand its community, which includes voting in new committers and ppmc members.

policy.doc.name: Apache Cookbook
section.name: community building
policy.statement: discussions of candidates and votes happen on the podling's private ppmc mailing list.

policy.doc.name: Apache Cookbook
section.name: podling releases
policy.statement: during incubation, we expect a podling to make several software releases that gradually progress towards being fully conformant to the asf release policy .

policy.doc.name: Apache Cookbook
section.name: podling releases
policy.statement: producing fully-conformant releases is a condition for graduation.

policy.doc.name: Apache Cookbook
section.name: podling releases
policy.statement: podling releases must also include the word "incubating" in any release file names and include a disclaimer or disclaimer-wip as per the incubator releases guide , to prevent any confusion as to the project’s status.

policy.doc.name: Apache Cookbook
section.name: two-phase vote on podling releases
policy.statement: voting on podling releases happens in two phases:

policy.doc.name: Apache Cookbook
section.name: two-phase vote on podling releases
policy.statement: first, the podling votes on the release on their dev mailing list.

policy.doc.name: Apache Cookbook
section.name: two-phase vote on podling releases
policy.statement: the vote is successful if there are at least three +1 votes from ppmc members, and more +1 than -1 votes from ppmc members.

policy.doc.name: Apache Cookbook
section.name: two-phase vote on podling releases
policy.statement: then, if that first vote is successful, the incubator pmc holds a vote on the incubator general mailing list.

policy.doc.name: Apache Cookbook
section.name: two-phase vote on podling releases
policy.statement: this is required to make the vote an act of the foundation, as for all asf releases.

policy.doc.name: Apache Cookbook
section.name: two-phase vote on podling releases
policy.statement: report votes from the podling dev list to the incubator pmc vote in the incubator pmc [vote] message, by explicitly mentioning the podling vote result and including a lists.apache.org link to the podling vote tally. this allows votes from mentors and other incubator pmc members to be binding in the incubator pmc vote, without people having to vote twice.

policy.doc.name: Apache Cookbook
section.name: two-phase vote on podling releases
policy.statement: both the podling and incubator votes follow the standard asf voting principles : they are majority votes that last at least 72 hours, and if people vote several times only their last vote counts.

policy.doc.name: Apache Cookbook
section.name: graduation readiness assessment
policy.statement: once the podling community starts feeling ready to graduate, they should make a self-assessment of that readiness.

policy.doc.name: Apache Cookbook
section.name: graduation readiness assessment
policy.statement: the maturity model maintained by the asf's community development pmc is a good canvas for that and can help discover things that might have been overlooked during incubation.

policy.doc.name: Apache Cookbook
section.name: graduation discussion
policy.statement: once the community and its incubation mentors feel that the podling is ready to graduate, based on their readiness self-assessment, a mentor or a member of the ppmc starts a [discuss] thread on the incubator general email list, proposing graduation and asking the incubator pmc to review the podling.

policy.doc.name: Apache Cookbook
section.name: transfering trademarks to the asf
policy.statement: if the people or organizations that donated the podling code to the asf own trademarks that the podling needs, they must transfer the trademarks to the asf before the podling can graduate.

policy.doc.name: Apache Cookbook
section.name: graduation vote
policy.statement: once the discussion dies down on the graduation proposal, a mentor or a member of the ppmc starts a [vote] thread on the incubator general mailing list, in which incubator pmc members cast their votes whether to recommend graduation to the asf's board of directors.

policy.doc.name: Apache Cookbook
section.name: graduation vote
policy.statement: this vote follows the standard asf voting principles .

policy.doc.name: Apache Cookbook
section.name: graduation vote
policy.statement: it's a majority vote that lasts at least 72 hours, and if people vote several times only their last vote counts.

policy.doc.name: Apache Cookbook
section.name: asf board resolution
policy.statement: once the incubator pmc votes to graduate a podling, the ipmc sends the board resolution that was created for the vote to the asf's board of directors.

policy.doc.name: Apache Cookbook
section.name: asf board resolution
policy.statement: the board vote is effective immediately, although the public minutes of the board meeting appear later, usually within a month.

policy.doc.name: Apache Cookbook
section.name: post-graduation tasks
policy.statement: once graduated, the podling needs to reflect its new status on the incubator status pages and make a few changes to its resources and processes.

policy.doc.name: Mentor Guide
section.name: add to incubation summary file
policy.statement: add the podling to the podling summary file in the "incubator" svn at content/podlings.xml (e.g. copy the entry from another podling that also has status="current") and see instructions .

policy.doc.name: Mentor Guide
section.name: initialize podling status page
policy.statement: a mentor needs to create the web page that will track the project's status.

policy.doc.name: Mentor Guide
section.name: initialize podling status page
policy.statement: a mentor will also need to update it until others in the project's ppmc can update it .

policy.doc.name: Mentor Guide
section.name: initialize podling status page
policy.statement: the status page is the incubator's record of the progress made.

policy.doc.name: Mentor Guide
section.name: initialize podling status page
policy.statement: it must be kept update to date during incubation.

policy.doc.name: Mentor Guide
section.name: initialize podling status page
policy.statement: as the startup process continues and resources are created the status should be updated.

policy.doc.name: Mentor Guide
section.name: initialize podling status page
policy.statement: the template contains lists of actions which may be needed to start up a podling. all those which do not apply should be deleted.

policy.doc.name: Mentor Guide
section.name: initialize podling status page
policy.statement: the status page is a useful aid to workflow. volunteers can use it to sign up to the various tasks and monitor their progress.

policy.doc.name: Mentor Guide
section.name: initialize podling status page
policy.statement: once the mailing lists are set up and prospective committers subscribe then these may be used for discussion.

policy.doc.name: Mentor Guide
section.name: resources
policy.statement: resources should be requested in a particular order, and based on paperwork processed. do not request source repositories before sgas are filed, for instance, if the source code is not already apache licensed or category a licensed.

policy.doc.name: Mentor Guide
section.name: resources
policy.statement: the proposal should include a list of required resources. all of these will require active set up.

policy.doc.name: Mentor Guide
section.name: resources
policy.statement: some are created by infrastructure after an appropriate request, others can be set up by any ipmc members (typically mentors).

policy.doc.name: Mentor Guide
section.name: resources
policy.statement: infra has a guide that you can use to understand the flow of resource requests, and should be used to guide you in requesting resources.

policy.doc.name: Mentor Guide
section.name: infra and the incubator
policy.statement: the first resources to be created are ldap and dns. these should be requested from infra via apache infra jira → create task

policy.doc.name: Mentor Guide
section.name: infra and the incubator
policy.statement: once these items are requested, mailing lists should be created next.

policy.doc.name: Mentor Guide
section.name: request mailing lists
policy.statement: apache mailing lists require volunteer moderators.

policy.doc.name: Mentor Guide
section.name: request mailing lists
policy.statement: new moderators can be changed later but at least one volunteer is required before the mailing lists can be set up.

policy.doc.name: Mentor Guide
section.name: request mailing lists
policy.statement: moderation is a reasonably easy task though moderators may want to set up spam filtering .

policy.doc.name: Mentor Guide
section.name: request mailing lists
policy.statement: having at least three moderators is recommended to spread the load.

policy.doc.name: Mentor Guide
section.name: request mailing lists
policy.statement: the proposal should contain the rest of the information that needs to be collected before the mailing lists can be requested.

policy.doc.name: Mentor Guide
section.name: request mailing lists
policy.statement: incubator is the responsible top level project. so the domain must be incubator.apache.org .

policy.doc.name: Mentor Guide
section.name: request mailing lists
policy.statement: a podling that is already established and using an existing user interaction channel may want to keep those resources around until they feel they have transitioned to the asf successfully.

policy.doc.name: Mentor Guide
section.name: request mailing lists
policy.statement: you will want to discuss this on your existing development lists.

policy.doc.name: Mentor Guide
section.name: request mailing lists
policy.statement: mailing lists creation is a task for the infrastructure team .

policy.doc.name: Mentor Guide
section.name: request mailing lists
policy.statement: prospective committers and mentors will need to subscribe. email them once the status file has been updated. inform any existing mailing lists or forums previously used by the project.

policy.doc.name: Mentor Guide
section.name: request mailing lists
policy.statement: once the commits list is created, the project must review the /incubator/${podling} tree, since any commits made prior to the list's creation will have generated no email trail.

policy.doc.name: Mentor Guide
section.name: mailing list administration
policy.statement: apache uses ezmlm .

policy.doc.name: Mentor Guide
section.name: mailing list transition
policy.statement: independent mailing lists and groups are perfectly acceptable but development should happen on the official mailing lists at apache.

policy.doc.name: Mentor Guide
section.name: mailing list transition
policy.statement: if a project has existing mailing lists, forums or groups the community needs to consider their future and plan for the transition to the official apache mailing lists.

policy.doc.name: Mentor Guide
section.name: mailing list transition
policy.statement: it may be useful to move development first to the official lists followed gradually by the user resources.

policy.doc.name: Mentor Guide
section.name: mailing list transition
policy.statement: note that subscribers of external mailing lists will not be automatically subscribed to the new incubator project mailing lists. instead, a note should be posted to the old external mailing list asking them to subscribe to the new list.

policy.doc.name: Mentor Guide
section.name: mentors must be on the ipmc
policy.statement: mentors must be on the ipmc.

policy.doc.name: Mentor Guide
section.name: mentors must be on the ipmc
policy.statement: this should be checked prior to beginning incubation.

policy.doc.name: Mentor Guide
section.name: mentors must be on the ipmc
policy.statement: any prospective mentors who are not yet on the ipmc should ask to be added (by election).

policy.doc.name: Mentor Guide
section.name: mentors must be on the ipmc
policy.statement: email the application to private@incubator.apache.org .

policy.doc.name: Mentor Guide
section.name: cla and ccla submission
policy.statement: prospective committers need to submit a contributor license agreement ( cla ).

policy.doc.name: Graduation Guide
section.name: whether to graduate to subproject or to top level project
policy.statement: as graduation approaches, this original preference should be reviewed based on where the project is now.

policy.doc.name: Graduation Guide
section.name: whether to graduate to subproject or to top level project
policy.statement: graduation as a subproject is only possible if the subproject still falls within the scope of the project and requires the consent of the project pmc .

policy.doc.name: Graduation Guide
section.name: whether to graduate to subproject or to top level project
policy.statement: graduation as a project requires the formation of the new project by the board.

policy.doc.name: Graduation Guide
section.name: whether to graduate to subproject or to top level project
policy.statement: the ipmc will also express a democratic opinion. for those seeking to graduate to a subproject this vote is to approve the transfer. for those seeking to graduation as a top level project, this will be a recommendation to the board.

policy.doc.name: Graduation Guide
section.name: before you graduate
policy.statement: before you start thinking about graduation, you need to make sure you are ready and meet the requirements imposed on apache projects.

policy.doc.name: Graduation Guide
section.name: checking the status file
policy.statement: before you are able to graduate, all tasks need to be completed.

policy.doc.name: Graduation Guide
section.name: checking the status file
policy.statement: the incubator pmc will check this file when they vote on the graduation of your project.

policy.doc.name: Graduation Guide
section.name: checking the status file
policy.statement: once all tasks are done and the listed criteria met, your project may be ready for graduation.

policy.doc.name: Graduation Guide
section.name: ensure suitable project name and product names
policy.statement: the "process for ensuring suitable project and product names" is mandatory for every podling which wants to graduate.

policy.doc.name: Graduation Guide
section.name: creating an apache release
policy.statement: projects need to cut releases. apache projects need to understand how to cut apache releases.

policy.doc.name: Graduation Guide
section.name: creating an apache release
policy.statement: if you are going to cut a release (which is highly recommended), then please read the incubator release management guide for hints, tips and guidelines for cutting a release that will get approved by the ipmc without problems.

policy.doc.name: Graduation Guide
section.name: creating an open and diverse community
policy.statement: a major criterion for graduation is to have developed an open and diverse meritocratic community.

policy.doc.name: Graduation Guide
section.name: creating an open and diverse community
policy.statement: the openness of the community is not only measured by the number of contributors. open and respectful discussions on the mailing lists are vital.

policy.doc.name: Graduation Guide
section.name: creating an open and diverse community
policy.statement: ways to resolve technical conflict without destroying personal relationships must be learned.

policy.doc.name: Graduation Guide
section.name: creating an open and diverse community
policy.statement: learning to use mailing lists effectively is very important.

policy.doc.name: Graduation Guide
section.name: creating an open and diverse community
policy.statement: the project is considered to have a diverse community when it is not highly dependent on any single contributor (there are at least 3 legally independent committers and there is no single company or entity that is vital to the success of the project).

policy.doc.name: Graduation Guide
section.name: creating an open and diverse community
policy.statement: you can mitigate this requirement by admitting more external contributors to your project that have no tie to the single entity.

policy.doc.name: Graduation Guide
section.name: other issues
policy.statement: podlings who are unsure if they are ready to graduate may want to consider completing the apache project maturity model .

policy.doc.name: Graduation Guide
section.name: the graduation process
policy.statement: graduating to a top level project top level projects are created by the board .

policy.doc.name: Graduation Guide
section.name: the graduation process
policy.statement: the incubator project management committee (ipmc) can therefore only recommend to the board that the project is ready to graduate to a top level project.

policy.doc.name: Graduation Guide
section.name: the graduation process
policy.statement: graduation to a top level project requires:

policy.doc.name: Graduation Guide
section.name: the graduation process
policy.statement: a charter for your project

policy.doc.name: Graduation Guide
section.name: the graduation process
policy.statement: a positive community graduation vote

policy.doc.name: Graduation Guide
section.name: the graduation process
policy.statement: a positive ipmc recommendation vote

policy.doc.name: Graduation Guide
section.name: the graduation process
policy.statement: the acceptance of the resolution by the board

policy.doc.name: Graduation Guide
section.name: community graduation vote
policy.statement: a community needs to be willing to govern itself before it can become a top level project.

policy.doc.name: Graduation Guide
section.name: community graduation vote
policy.statement: a good way to demonstrate this is through a free vote (by the community) on the graduation proposal. this vote is not a requirement but is recommended.

policy.doc.name: Graduation Guide
section.name: community graduation vote
policy.statement: it is unlikely that ipmc members will vote to approve graduation unless the mentors and community positively express their readiness for graduation.

policy.doc.name: Graduation Guide
section.name: preparing a charter
policy.statement: so, in this case a suitable board resolution should be drawn up by the community advised by the mentors .

policy.doc.name: Graduation Guide
section.name: preparing a charter
policy.statement: committers can access the podling template for resolutions in the committers svn repository .

policy.doc.name: Graduation Guide
section.name: preparing a charter
policy.statement: your whimsy roster also includes a feature to draft a resolution.

policy.doc.name: Graduation Guide
section.name: preparing a charter
policy.statement: the original proposal and the status document should be consulted when creating this document.

policy.doc.name: Graduation Guide
section.name: preparing a charter
policy.statement: the board resolution is the ultimate definition of the scope of an apache project.

policy.doc.name: Graduation Guide
section.name: preparing a charter
policy.statement: if you read these resolutions you also see that you need to appoint a chair for your project. it is up to the ppmc to choose one person to act as the chair after graduation.

policy.doc.name: Graduation Guide
section.name: the recommendation vote
policy.statement: the resolution should be proposed on the general incubator list before a vote is started to allow feedback.

policy.doc.name: Graduation Guide
section.name: the recommendation vote
policy.statement: once a consensus has been reached, a vote should be started on the same general incubator list by a member of the ppmc proposing that the ipmc recommends the resolution to the board .

policy.doc.name: Graduation Guide
section.name: submission of the resolution to the board
policy.statement: top level projects are created by a resolution by the board .

policy.doc.name: Graduation Guide
section.name: submission of the resolution to the board
policy.statement: once the resolution has been finalized and consensus reached, it should be submitted to the board.

policy.doc.name: Graduation Guide
section.name: submission of the resolution to the board
policy.statement: for inclusion in the agenda for the next meeting, the resolution should be submitted at least 72 hours before that meeting.

policy.doc.name: Graduation Guide
section.name: press releases for new tlps
policy.statement: once there is clear consensus that the recommendation will happen, a member of the ppmc should contact asf marketing publicity at press(at)apache(dot)org if your project is interested in a formal press release announcing your graduation.

policy.doc.name: Graduation Guide
section.name: press releases for new tlps
policy.statement: this should be done roughly at the same time that the board resolution is sent.

policy.doc.name: Graduation Guide
section.name: graduating to a subproject
policy.statement: subprojects are accepted by a project management committee.

policy.doc.name: Graduation Guide
section.name: graduating to a subproject
policy.statement: the incubator project management committee needs to approve the graduation of the podling to a subproject.

policy.doc.name: Graduation Guide
section.name: community graduation vote
policy.statement: becoming a subproject is a voluntary process, and should be accepted by the community becoming a sub-project.

policy.doc.name: Graduation Guide
section.name: community graduation vote
policy.statement: it should be clear to the ppmc and committers for the podling what the make up of the new sub-project should be, e.g. who belongs on the receiving pmc, who will be a committer.

policy.doc.name: Graduation Guide
section.name: community graduation vote
policy.statement: this vote should happen on a public dev list.

policy.doc.name: Graduation Guide
section.name: subproject acceptance vote
policy.statement: a formal vote by the project pmc to accept the podling as a subproject is a prerequisite.

policy.doc.name: Graduation Guide
section.name: graduation approval vote
policy.statement: once the accepting tlp have voted to accept the podling and the podling has voted to become a subproject, noticed should be sent to the ipmc via general at incubator.a.o email list indicating that the podling will become a subproject.

policy.doc.name: Graduation Guide
section.name: graduation approval vote
policy.statement: if after 72 hours no issues are raised, the podling may be considered a subproject of the accepting tlp.

policy.doc.name: Graduation Guide
section.name: graduation approval vote
policy.statement: likewise, if any ipmc member raises an issue, that should be discussed.

policy.doc.name: Graduation Guide
section.name: graduation approval vote
policy.statement: if the issue is addressed, the member raising the issue should indicate they rescind their concerns or otherwise consider them resolved.

policy.doc.name: Retirement Guide
section.name: deciding to retire
policy.statement: in the vast majority of cases, a podling decides to retire on its own and that decision is later formally ratified by the incubator pmc; very rarely, the ipmc may act unilaterally.

policy.doc.name: Retirement Guide
section.name: deciding to retire
policy.statement: before the ipmc gets involved, a public discussion and community vote should be held on the podling's dev list. this ensures that all podling stakeholders are properly informed and have the opportunity to participate in the decision.

policy.doc.name: Retirement Guide
section.name: deciding to retire
policy.statement: the final decision to retire the podling takes the form of a vote by the ipmc on general@incubator. the vote should be by lazy consensus.

policy.doc.name: Retirement Guide
section.name: steps to retirement
policy.statement: once the ipmc vote to retire the podling has closed, a mentor or other volunteer needs to perform the following steps.

policy.doc.name: Retirement Guide
section.name: steps to retirement
policy.statement: update content/podlings.xml :

policy.doc.name: Retirement Guide
section.name: steps to retirement
policy.statement: update podling status to "retired".

policy.doc.name: Retirement Guide
section.name: steps to retirement
policy.statement: add an "enddate" attribute set to the date that the ipmc vote concluded.

policy.doc.name: Retirement Guide
section.name: steps to retirement
policy.statement: remove the "reporting" element.

policy.doc.name: Retirement Guide
section.name: steps to retirement
policy.statement: add the "resolution" element.

policy.doc.name: Retirement Guide
section.name: steps to retirement
policy.statement: update the podling's status page with a prominent message indicating when the podling retired: p span class="retired" the ${podling} podling retired on xxxx-xx-xx /span /p .

policy.doc.name: Retirement Guide
section.name: steps to retirement
policy.statement: has the copyright checkbox of the podling's incubation status page been checked off?

policy.doc.name: Retirement Guide
section.name: steps to retirement
policy.statement: if not, try to resolve it. if it cannot be resolved, the podling's source code must be removed from version control.

policy.doc.name: Retirement Guide
section.name: steps to retirement
policy.statement: it may be that the podling is moving or returning development elsewhere. if so, then modify the resolution attributes appropriately.

policy.doc.name: Retirement Guide
section.name: steps to retirement
policy.statement: delete the podling's dist dir, so that its releases will no longer be mirrored: svn remove https://dist.apache.org/repos/dist/release/incubator/${podling}

policy.doc.name: Retirement Guide
section.name: steps to retirement
policy.statement: create a file retired.txt at the top-level of each podling source repository.

policy.doc.name: Retirement Guide
section.name: steps to retirement
policy.statement: add entries to asf-mailer.conf and send mail to cvs at incubator.apache.org

policy.doc.name: Retirement Guide
section.name: steps to retirement
policy.statement: remove entries from asf-authorization - this makes the directory rw to the incubator pmc.

policy.doc.name: Retirement Guide
section.name: steps to retirement
policy.statement: after infra modifies the website svn permissions, disable the podling website by installing an .htaccess like this

policy.doc.name: Retirement Guide
section.name: steps to retirement
policy.statement: file at the root of the podling website dir which consists of only a redirect to the podling status page.

policy.doc.name: Retirement Guide
section.name: steps to retirement
policy.statement: - when all steps towards retirement are done, announce completeness on general@incubator.

policy.doc.name: Retirement Guide
section.name: steps to retirement
policy.statement: - indicate that the podling is closed down in the next board report.

policy.doc.name: Retirement Guide
section.name: steps to retirement
policy.statement: the user accounts of the projects committers do not need to be removed.

policy.doc.name: Release Management Guide
section.name: what goes into an asf release
policy.statement: a podling community should begin to familiarize themselves with the asf policies for releases.

policy.doc.name: Release Management Guide
section.name: what goes into an asf release
policy.statement: releases are always produced by an apache pmc, and for podlings, this pmc is the ipmc. this is why it is mandatory to have at least 3 +1 votes from ipmc members.

policy.doc.name: Release Management Guide
section.name: what goes into an asf release
policy.statement: usually, your mentors (who are also ipmc members) will vote on your releases, but if needed, other ipmc members will as well.

policy.doc.name: Release Management Guide
section.name: what goes into an asf release
policy.statement: ipmc members will check for compliance with the asf policies and with incubator policies.

policy.doc.name: Release Management Guide
section.name: what goes into an asf release
policy.statement: anybody reviewing your releases will explain what they checked and what they found. they will also rate the severity of any issues. some issues may be blockers. others issues may be resolved in later releases. those voting on the release will base their votes on this information.

policy.doc.name: Release Management Guide
section.name: requesting feedback on interim non-asf releases
policy.statement: we want to welcome projects with active communities. to smooth this process, projects may need to make a few non-asf releases after incubation begins.

policy.doc.name: Release Management Guide
section.name: requesting feedback on interim non-asf releases
policy.statement: a non-asf release may or may not be staged on asf infrastructure for a vote, but it is distributed via non-asf infrastructure, and is either not linked from a podling's website, or is linked but clearly marked as a non-asf release.

policy.doc.name: Release Management Guide
section.name: requesting feedback on interim non-asf releases
policy.statement: podlings can use non-asf releases as an opportunity to find asf policy violations and begin resolving them.

policy.doc.name: Release Management Guide
section.name: requesting feedback on interim non-asf releases
policy.statement: podlings can request feedback by starting a "[discuss]" thread on general@incubator.apache.org. podlings can decide whether they prefer a "[discuss]" thread or a "[vote]" thread.

policy.doc.name: Release Management Guide
section.name: requesting feedback on interim non-asf releases
policy.statement: discussion should give podlings feedback on what they would need to do to bring their release in line with the requirements of an official asf release.

policy.doc.name: Release Management Guide
section.name: requesting feedback on interim non-asf releases
policy.statement: podlings will be responsible for capturing feedback in work items for their project.

policy.doc.name: Release Management Guide
section.name: requesting feedback on interim non-asf releases
policy.statement: feedback provided in a discussion thread will not block a non-asf release.

policy.doc.name: Release Management Guide
section.name: requesting feedback on interim non-asf releases
policy.statement: but the asf will not take on legal liability for these releases.

policy.doc.name: Release Management Guide
section.name: requesting feedback on interim non-asf releases
policy.statement: a podling will need to successfully make several asf releases before it can graduate from the incubator.

policy.doc.name: Release Management Guide
section.name: requesting feedback on interim non-asf releases
policy.statement: asking for feedback for non-asf releases is not obligatory. it is one of the services that the apache incubator offers our podling communities.

policy.doc.name: Release Management Guide
section.name: podling constraints
policy.statement: the incubator policies applys two additional constraints to podlings for their releases.

policy.doc.name: Release Management Guide
section.name: podling constraints
policy.statement: - release artifacts must include incubating in the final file name

policy.doc.name: Release Management Guide
section.name: podling constraints
policy.statement: - release artifacts must include one of two disclaimers

policy.doc.name: Release Management Guide
section.name: podling constraints
policy.statement: for a podling to receive full permission from the ipmc to execute the release, the release vote must be held on the incubator general list and pass based on the standard package release voting rules.

policy.doc.name: Release Management Guide
section.name: podling constraints
policy.statement: only incubator pmc votes are binding, but everyone is encouraged to vote.

policy.doc.name: Release Management Guide
section.name: podling constraints
policy.statement: the incubator pmc expects the source releases to be staged on https://dist.apache.org/repos/dist/dev/incubator/$podlingname so that they can easily be moved to the release location via svn mv.

policy.doc.name: Release Management Guide
section.name: choice of disclaimers
policy.statement: when making a release, a podling has a choice of using one of two disclaimers, the standard disclaimer or the work in progress disclaimer.

policy.doc.name: Release Management Guide
section.name: choice of disclaimers
policy.statement: if it is your first release, it is recommended that you use the work in progress disclaimer. this disclaimer allows you to list any non-compliance with asf policy and ipmc members are still be able to give your release a +1 vote.

policy.doc.name: Release Management Guide
section.name: choice of disclaimers
policy.statement: any releases using the work in progress disclaimer must still be legal and follow the terms of any 3rd party licenses, even if they are not compatible with the apache license.

policy.doc.name: Release Management Guide
section.name: choice of disclaimers
policy.statement: by the time you graduate all issues listed in the disclaimer need to have been corrected, and you must use the standard disclaimer text.

policy.doc.name: Release Management Guide
section.name: choice of disclaimers
policy.statement: if a podling chooses uses the standards disclaimer, then the release must comply with all asf policies.
